title: 106_s1096
content: The Act titled "Mississippi Valley National Historical Park Act of 1999" includes provisions for the establishment and administration of the historical park in Blytheville, Arkansas. It also involves the transfer of jurisdiction of Eaker Air Force Base for the park and the acquisition of Chickasawba Mound for inclusion. Congress finds that the central and lower Mississippi Valley region has a rich history with Native American societies and has been influenced by Spanish, French, English, and American societies over the past 450 years. Blytheville, Arkansas, located in the Mississippi Valley region, is home to the former Eaker Air Force Base, which contains 14 archaeological sites associated with Native Americans. These sites are valuable for illustrating and interpreting the heritage of the United States. The heritage of the United States at archaeological sites like Chickasawba Mound in Blytheville, Arkansas, has been recognized by the National Park Service. These sites are important for educating and inspiring present and future generations, but there is no unified heritage park for the central Mississippi Valley region within the National Park Service. Blytheville, Arkansas, also has other significant natural, seismic, cultural, and recreational resources. The central Mississippi Valley region's heritage sites and resources need recognition through a national historical park. The closure of Eaker Air Force Base in Blytheville, Arkansas provides an opportunity to establish this park to protect archaeological sites and preserve the region's natural, seismic, cultural, and recreational heritage. The central Mississippi Valley region's heritage sites and resources need recognition through a national historical park to protect archaeological sites and preserve the natural, seismic, cultural, and recreational heritage for present and future generations of Americans. SEC. 3. Establishing the Mississippi Valley National Historical Park in Blytheville, Arkansas. The Mississippi Valley National Historical Park is established in Blytheville, Arkansas, encompassing approximately 570 acres of properties associated with the region's heritage. This includes the former Eaker Air Force Base and the Chickasawba Mound archaeological site. The boundaries also extend to any additional property authorized for acquisition for the park. The Mississippi Valley National Historical Park in Blytheville, Arkansas, covers 570 acres with properties like the Eaker Air Force Base and Chickasawba Mound. Additional properties can be acquired for the park through new laws. Transfer of jurisdiction for historical park at Eaker Air Force Base. The Secretary of Defense will transfer archaeological sites and additional real property at former Eaker Air Force Base to the Secretary of the Interior for the development of visitor and administrative facilities for a historical park. The Secretary of Defense will transfer up to 15 acres of land jointly selected with the Secretary of the Interior for use in a historical park. The Secretary of the Interior will determine the legal description through a survey paid for by them. The Secretary of the Interior may acquire the Chickasawba Mound archaeological site for the historical park. The Secretary of the Interior administers the historical park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act. They may enter into cooperative agreements for preservation and development, subject to certain conditions. The Secretary of the Interior may acquire real property within the historical park using appropriated or donated funds, donations, or exchanges, subject to specific conditions. If a project assisted under a cooperative agreement is used contrary to the park's purposes, the United States has the right to reimbursement of funds or a proportion of the project's increased value.
